column4: um, how can I backup all my programs and settings (let's say, if i'm gonna install on another drive)?
um, LjL, what exactly does that backup?

1) you can get a list of the packages you have installed using the method above  2) to back up your data and personal program settings, you will need to back up your /home  3) if you manually changed anything in /etc, you may want to back it up
it doesn't backup anything, it merely creates a list of the programs you have installed, and you can easily re-install them from that list later
and how about if i wanna backup stuff like, um, my compiz settings?
if i backup my entire /home dir and overwrite the other installation...well, will it work?
what do you mean "overwrite the other installation"?
overwrite the /home dir on the new installation
yes, that's the idea. only one caveat: if you have more than one user, you might have to make sure the user ID's match. if you only have one user, it will be UID 1000, so that won't be a problem.
will that backup my programs as well?

no, as i told you... backing up /home will back up your *settings*. you *should not* back up your programs - that would result in a mess. just generate a *list* of the programs you have installed, and then reinstall them (which, as the bot said, can be done quite automatically)
if your internet connection isn't too fast for that to be comfortable, you can possibly back up /var/cache/apt/archives (which contains the .deb files of everything you downloaded)
reinstall using the command above, yes
